description: Leadership consistently learns about problems — project delays, team issues, partner friction — from other people rather than from the EM. Trust erodes rapidly, autonomy gets revoked, and the EM's reputation for reliability collapses as surprises accumulate.

title: AP-24: Empire Building — EM expands scope and absorbs teams to grow their org size rather than for customer or business impact. Resources get spread thin across non-critical work, peers lose respect for the political maneuvering, and the bloated org becomes a target during the next rebalancing cycle.
description: EM expands scope and absorbs teams to grow their org size rather than for customer or business impact. Resources get spread thin across non-critical work, peers lose respect for the political maneuvering, and the bloated org becomes a target during the next rebalancing cycle.

title: AP-25: The Blank Check Mentality — EM asks for resources without cost consciousness, ROI justification, or capacity models linking headcount to deliverables. Finance and leadership see engineering as a cost center, budget requests get denied, and the team eventually faces forced cuts.
description: EM asks for resources without cost consciousness, ROI justification, or capacity models linking headcount to deliverables. Finance and leadership see engineering as a cost center, budget requests get denied, and the team eventually faces forced cuts.

title: AP-26: Analysis Paralysis — Every decision requires exhaustive analysis and data-gathering before action, trapping the team in perpetual research mode. Opportunities expire, competitors ship, and the team's risk aversion becomes the biggest risk of all.
description: Every decision requires exhaustive analysis and data-gathering before action, trapping the team in perpetual research mode. Opportunities expire, competitors ship, and the team's risk aversion becomes the biggest risk of all.

title: AP-27: The Yes Machine — EM agrees to every request from stakeholders without pushing back or making trade-offs visible, leaving the team chronically overcommitted. Deadlines slip, quality degrades, and credibility collapses as the gap between promises and delivery widens every quarter.
description: EM agrees to every request from stakeholders without pushing back or making trade-offs visible, leaving the team chronically overcommitted. Deadlines slip, quality degrades, and credibility collapses as the gap between promises and delivery widens every quarter.

title: AP-28: The IC Trap — EM spends their time writing code and reviewing PRs instead of doing the actual management work their team needs. Team growth stalls, 1:1s become status updates, and the EM becomes an expensive IC while management gaps compound.
description: EM spends their time writing code and reviewing PRs instead of doing the actual management work their team needs. Team growth stalls, 1:1s become status updates, and the EM becomes an expensive IC while management gaps compound.

title: AP-29: Death by Metrics — EM drowns the team in dashboards, OKR tracking, and velocity reports until measuring the work consumes more energy than doing the work. Engineers become cynical about metrics, game the numbers, and real productivity declines behind a wall of charts.
description: EM drowns the team in dashboards, OKR tracking, and velocity reports until measuring the work consumes more energy than doing the work. Engineers become cynical about metrics, game the numbers, and real productivity declines behind a wall of charts.

title: AP-30: The Consensus Trap — EM treats every decision as requiring unanimous agreement, turning consensus into a procrastination mechanism. Decisions stall for weeks, the loudest dissenter holds veto power, and the team learns that objecting is the easiest way to delay anything.
description: EM treats every decision as requiring unanimous agreement, turning consensus into a procrastination mechanism. Decisions stall for weeks, the loudest dissenter holds veto power, and the team learns that objecting is the easiest way to delay anything.

title: AP-31: Meeting Debt & Process Cargo Cult — Team drowns in ceremonies, syncs, and rituals that nobody can justify, with agile processes adopted by name without understanding their purpose. Engineers get less than two hours of uninterrupted focus time per day, and real work happens only after hours.
description: Team drowns in ceremonies, syncs, and rituals that nobody can justify, with agile processes adopted by name without understanding their purpose. Engineers get less than two hours of uninterrupted focus time per day, and real work happens only after hours.

title: AP-32: Documentation Hoarding — EM mandates documentation for everything but never ensures it's maintained, discoverable, or useful. A graveyard of stale pages accumulates, engineers stop trusting docs, and tribal knowledge becomes the de facto system of record.
description: EM mandates documentation for everything but never ensures it's maintained, discoverable, or useful. A graveyard of stale pages accumulates, engineers stop trusting docs, and tribal knowledge becomes the de facto system of record.

title: AP-33: The Hero EM — Manager solves every problem personally, takes over every escalation, and absorbs all challenging work. The team never develops independence, senior engineers atrophy, and the EM becomes a bottleneck that limits the org's capacity to their personal bandwidth.
description: Manager solves every problem personally, takes over every escalation, and absorbs all challenging work. The team never develops independence, senior engineers atrophy, and the EM becomes a bottleneck that limits the org's capacity to their personal bandwidth.

title: AP-35: The Infinite Runway — EM treats cloud/infra spend as unbounded and never prioritizes cost optimization. Costs grow unchecked until finance forces an emergency reduction, diverting the team from planned work to reactive cost-cutting under pressure.
description: EM treats cloud/infra spend as unbounded and never prioritizes cost optimization. Costs grow unchecked until finance forces an emergency reduction, diverting the team from planned work to reactive cost-cutting under pressure.

title: AP-37: Compliance Cramming — EM treats compliance as a periodic audit exercise, achieving minimal technical compliance without genuine security posture improvement. Day-to-day practices drift from documented standards, and audit preparation becomes a recurring fire drill that disrupts planned work.
description: EM treats compliance as a periodic audit exercise, achieving minimal technical compliance without genuine security posture improvement. Day-to-day practices drift from documented standards, and audit preparation becomes a recurring fire drill that disrupts planned work.

title: AP-38: The Ivory Tower Architect — EM pushes architectural purity and over-engineering at the expense of pragmatic delivery. Systems are technically impressive but ship late, the team gold-plates solutions nobody asked for, and business impact suffers while architecture reviews multiply.
description: EM pushes architectural purity and over-engineering at the expense of pragmatic delivery. Systems are technically impressive but ship late, the team gold-plates solutions nobody asked for, and business impact suffers while architecture reviews multiply.

title: AP-40: The Missing Stair — EM tolerates a known toxic or underperforming person because the team has learned to 'work around' them. High performers leave frustrated by the inequity, team standards erode, and the EM's credibility collapses when the situation inevitably escalates.
description: EM tolerates a known toxic or underperforming person because the team has learned to 'work around' them. High performers leave frustrated by the inequity, team standards erode, and the EM's credibility collapses when the situation inevitably escalates.

title: AP-41: Culture Tourism — EM treats culture building as periodic events — off-sites, pizza, team lunches — rather than daily structural practices. Surface-level perks mask unaddressed dysfunction, and engineers see through the performative gestures to the real culture underneath.
description: EM treats culture building as periodic events — off-sites, pizza, team lunches — rather than daily structural practices. Surface-level perks mask unaddressed dysfunction, and engineers see through the performative gestures to the real culture underneath.

title: AP-42: Peanut Butter Spreading — EM distributes resources evenly across all projects instead of concentrating on highest-impact bets. Everything moves slowly, nothing ships with impact, and the team delivers mediocre results across the board instead of excellence where it matters.
description: EM distributes resources evenly across all projects instead of concentrating on highest-impact bets. Everything moves slowly, nothing ships with impact, and the team delivers mediocre results across the board instead of excellence where it matters.

title: AP-43: The Telephone Game — Information degrades as it passes through management layers because there's no source-of-truth documentation. Teams operate on conflicting versions of reality, decisions get relitigated, and alignment meetings multiply to compensate for broken information flow.
description: Information degrades as it passes through management layers because there's no source-of-truth documentation. Teams operate on conflicting versions of reality, decisions get relitigated, and alignment meetings multiply to compensate for broken information flow.

title: AP-44: The Recency Trap — EM's performance assessment is dominated by the last 6 weeks instead of the full review period. Engineers who had a strong H1 but quiet H2 get underrated, while those who time visible work to review season get overrated, eroding trust in the process.
description: EM's performance assessment is dominated by the last 6 weeks instead of the full review period. Engineers who had a strong H1 but quiet H2 get underrated, while those who time visible work to review season get overrated, eroding trust in the process.

title: AP-46: The Vibes-Based Hire — EM relies on gut feeling and 'culture fit' rather than structured evaluation in hiring. Biased and unpredictable outcomes follow — the team clones its existing demographic, strong candidates are rejected for vague reasons, and hiring quality varies wildly by interviewer.
description: EM relies on gut feeling and 'culture fit' rather than structured evaluation in hiring. Biased and unpredictable outcomes follow — the team clones its existing demographic, strong candidates are rejected for vague reasons, and hiring quality varies wildly by interviewer.

title: AP-48: The Lagging-Only Dashboard — EM only tracks lagging indicators — incidents, attrition, missed deadlines — and never has early warning signals for emerging problems. By the time a metric turns red the damage is done, and recovery takes months instead of the days a leading indicator would have enabled.
description: EM only tracks lagging indicators — incidents, attrition, missed deadlines — and never has early warning signals for emerging problems. By the time a metric turns red the damage is done, and recovery takes months instead of the days a leading indicator would have enabled.

title: AP-49: The Invisible Tech Debt — Tech debt accumulates invisibly because it's never quantified, tracked, or communicated to stakeholders in business terms. Leadership sees no reason to fund remediation, engineers suffer in silence, and velocity degrades until a catastrophic failure forces attention.
description: Tech debt accumulates invisibly because it's never quantified, tracked, or communicated to stakeholders in business terms. Leadership sees no reason to fund remediation, engineers suffer in silence, and velocity degrades until a catastrophic failure forces attention.

title: AP-50: The Silo Builder — EM optimizes for their team's local success at the expense of cross-team collaboration and org-wide outcomes. Peer teams learn to route around the silo, leadership loses trust, and the team's wins come at the cost of org-wide velocity.
description: EM optimizes for their team's local success at the expense of cross-team collaboration and org-wide outcomes. Peer teams learn to route around the silo, leadership loses trust, and the team's wins come at the cost of org-wide velocity.

title: AP-51: The Accidental Manager — Someone is promoted into management because they were the best IC, without any management training, coaching, or support. The org loses a great engineer and gains a struggling manager, and the team suffers through months of avoidable mistakes.
description: Someone is promoted into management because they were the best IC, without any management training, coaching, or support. The org loses a great engineer and gains a struggling manager, and the team suffers through months of avoidable mistakes.

title: AP-52: The Task-List OKR — Team's OKRs are formatted as task lists with binary checkboxes rather than measurable outcomes. Goal-setting becomes project management theater — checking boxes doesn't prove impact, and the team never learns whether their work actually moved the needle.
description: Team's OKRs are formatted as task lists with binary checkboxes rather than measurable outcomes. Goal-setting becomes project management theater — checking boxes doesn't prove impact, and the team never learns whether their work actually moved the needle.

title: AP-53: The Urgency Treadmill — Everything is urgent and nothing is strategic — the team constantly reacts to the loudest stakeholder or latest fire. Long-term initiatives never gain traction, engineers burn out from context-switching, and the team's impact stays flat despite working harder.
description: Everything is urgent and nothing is strategic — the team constantly reacts to the loudest stakeholder or latest fire. Long-term initiatives never gain traction, engineers burn out from context-switching, and the team's impact stays flat despite working harder.

title: AP-54: The Wrecking Ball — New leader makes drastic changes in their first weeks without understanding context, scrapping processes and reorganizing teams based on assumptions. Institutional knowledge is destroyed, trust collapses, and the very problems the changes aimed to fix get worse.
description: New leader makes drastic changes in their first weeks without understanding context, scrapping processes and reorganizing teams based on assumptions. Institutional knowledge is destroyed, trust collapses, and the very problems the changes aimed to fix get worse.

title: AP-55: Budget in a Vacuum — Engineering leader plans budget in isolation without cross-functional input from product, finance, or peer engineering teams. Budget reviews become adversarial, asks get cut disproportionately, and the org loses credibility as a strategic partner.
description: Engineering leader plans budget in isolation without cross-functional input from product, finance, or peer engineering teams. Budget reviews become adversarial, asks get cut disproportionately, and the org loses credibility as a strategic partner.

title: AP-56: The Stress Funnel — Manager passes organizational pressure, political conflicts, and exec anxiety directly to engineers instead of filtering it into actionable context. The team becomes anxious and distracted, productivity drops, and engineers start job-searching to escape the stress.
description: Manager passes organizational pressure, political conflicts, and exec anxiety directly to engineers instead of filtering it into actionable context. The team becomes anxious and distracted, productivity drops, and engineers start job-searching to escape the stress.

title: AP-57: Alert Noise Normalization — Team accumulates alerts over time but nobody removes them because engineers fear deleting one that might matter. Non-actionable noise grows until on-call is desensitized, real incidents get slower response, and alert fatigue becomes a reliability risk itself.
description: Team accumulates alerts over time but nobody removes them because engineers fear deleting one that might matter. Non-actionable noise grows until on-call is desensitized, real incidents get slower response, and alert fatigue becomes a reliability risk itself.

title: AP-58: The Interview Marathon — Hiring process has grown to 7-8 rounds through risk aversion, with each bad hire triggering another interview stage rather than improving existing ones. Top candidates drop out mid-process, offer acceptance rate plummets, and the team selects for persistence over talent.
description: Hiring process has grown to 7-8 rounds through risk aversion, with each bad hire triggering another interview stage rather than improving existing ones. Top candidates drop out mid-process, offer acceptance rate plummets, and the team selects for persistence over talent.

title: AP-59: The Order Taker — Engineering leader defers entirely to product for direction, never challenging priorities, proposing technical opportunities, or shaping strategy. Engineering becomes a feature factory with no technical voice, and the leader's credibility as a strategic partner erodes.
description: Engineering leader defers entirely to product for direction, never challenging priorities, proposing technical opportunities, or shaping strategy. Engineering becomes a feature factory with no technical voice, and the leader's credibility as a strategic partner erodes.

title: AP-60: The Feedback Avoidance Loop — Manager avoids giving negative performance feedback until it's too late, letting minor issues compound into serious underperformance. The first honest feedback the engineer receives is a PIP or a low rating, destroying trust and making recovery nearly impossible.
description: Manager avoids giving negative performance feedback until it's too late, letting minor issues compound into serious underperformance. The first honest feedback the engineer receives is a PIP or a low rating, destroying trust and making recovery nearly impossible.

title: AP-61: Incident Amnesia — Team runs post-mortems after every incident but action items die in a backlog. The same class of incident recurs because learning never converts to systemic change, and the post-mortem becomes a ritual that breeds cynicism rather than resilience.
description: Team runs post-mortems after every incident but action items die in a backlog. The same class of incident recurs because learning never converts to systemic change, and the post-mortem becomes a ritual that breeds cynicism rather than resilience.

title: AP-62: Resume-Driven Architecture — Technology choices are driven by what looks impressive on resumes rather than what solves the actual problem. The team adopts Kubernetes for 3 services or microservices for a 5-person team, adding operational complexity that dwarfs the engineering value.
description: Technology choices are driven by what looks impressive on resumes rather than what solves the actual problem. The team adopts Kubernetes for 3 services or microservices for a 5-person team, adding operational complexity that dwarfs the engineering value.

title: AP-63: The Ostrich Leader — Leader avoids making difficult organizational decisions, letting dysfunctional dynamics persist and hoping problems resolve themselves. Org health slowly deteriorates, top performers leave the dysfunction, and the problems compound until they become crises.
description: Leader avoids making difficult organizational decisions, letting dysfunctional dynamics persist and hoping problems resolve themselves. Org health slowly deteriorates, top performers leave the dysfunction, and the problems compound until they become crises.

title: AP-64: The Goodhart Trap — Once a metric becomes a target, the team optimizes for the metric rather than the outcome it was supposed to measure. Velocity numbers go up while actual delivery value goes down, the metric loses diagnostic power, and real performance becomes invisible.
description: Once a metric becomes a target, the team optimizes for the metric rather than the outcome it was supposed to measure. Velocity numbers go up while actual delivery value goes down, the metric loses diagnostic power, and real performance becomes invisible.

title: AP-65: The Talent Hostage — Manager hoards talent by blocking internal transfers, withholding growth opportunities, or creating dependency. The team becomes a place people can't leave rather than a place they want to stay, and the best engineers leave the company entirely.
description: Manager hoards talent by blocking internal transfers, withholding growth opportunities, or creating dependency. The team becomes a place people can't leave rather than a place they want to stay, and the best engineers leave the company entirely.

title: AP-66: The Ivory Tower Strategy — Leadership creates a strategic vision in documents and presentations but never translates it into actionable work for teams. Engineers cannot connect their daily work to the strategy, the gap between intent and execution widens quarterly, and OKRs drift into busywork.
description: Leadership creates a strategic vision in documents and presentations but never translates it into actionable work for teams. Engineers cannot connect their daily work to the strategy, the gap between intent and execution widens quarterly, and OKRs drift into busywork.

title: AP-67: The Toil Spiral — Team neglects operational health — toil reduction, developer experience, and technical debt — because feature delivery always wins the prioritization fight. Accumulated neglect eventually degrades velocity so badly that the team can't ship features either.
description: Team neglects operational health — toil reduction, developer experience, and technical debt — because feature delivery always wins the prioritization fight. Accumulated neglect eventually degrades velocity so badly that the team can't ship features either.

title: AP-68: The Stakeholder Surprise — Engineering leader avoids surfacing technical risks, timeline slips, and scope changes until the last possible moment. Stakeholders are repeatedly blindsided, trust erodes rapidly, and leadership starts micromanaging or routing around engineering entirely.
description: Engineering leader avoids surfacing technical risks, timeline slips, and scope changes until the last possible moment. Stakeholders are repeatedly blindsided, trust erodes rapidly, and leadership starts micromanaging or routing around engineering entirely.

title: AP-69: The 100% Utilization Fallacy — Manager allocates 100% of engineering capacity to planned work, leaving zero buffer for unplanned work, interrupts, or learning. Projects chronically miss deadlines because the plan assumed ideal conditions that never exist, and the team has no capacity to absorb reality.
description: Manager allocates 100% of engineering capacity to planned work, leaving zero buffer for unplanned work, interrupts, or learning. Projects chronically miss deadlines because the plan assumed ideal conditions that never exist, and the team has no capacity to absorb reality.

title: AP-70: The Reassurance Trap — During periods of uncertainty — layoffs, reorgs, strategy pivots — the manager offers vague reassurances that ring hollow. Trust is destroyed faster than honest acknowledgment of difficulty would, and the team disengages or begins job-searching in silence.
description: During periods of uncertainty — layoffs, reorgs, strategy pivots — the manager offers vague reassurances that ring hollow. Trust is destroyed faster than honest acknowledgment of difficulty would, and the team disengages or begins job-searching in silence.

title: AP-71: Vulnerability Noise Blindness — Automated security scanners generate hundreds of findings per week but without effective triage or noise reduction. The team becomes desensitized, treating the vulnerability backlog as unfixable background noise while critical issues hide in plain sight.
description: Automated security scanners generate hundreds of findings per week but without effective triage or noise reduction. The team becomes desensitized, treating the vulnerability backlog as unfixable background noise while critical issues hide in plain sight.

title: AP-72: The Shadow Bypass — Engineers routinely circumvent security controls — disabling scanners, skipping threat modeling, using personal credentials — because security is perceived as friction. Each bypass normalizes the next, widening the gap between documented security posture and actual practice.
description: Engineers routinely circumvent security controls — disabling scanners, skipping threat modeling, using personal credentials — because security is perceived as friction. Each bypass normalizes the next, widening the gap between documented security posture and actual practice.

title: AP-73: The Certification Facade — Team maintains compliance certifications and passes audits, but certified practices are only followed during audit preparation. Day-to-day security posture drifts far from documented standards, creating a dangerous gap between paper compliance and actual risk.
description: Team maintains compliance certifications and passes audits, but certified practices are only followed during audit preparation. Day-to-day security posture drifts far from documented standards, creating a dangerous gap between paper compliance and actual risk.

title: Your Top Performer Gives 2 Weeks Notice
description: Your best senior engineer has an offer from a competitor. They seem decided but are giving you a courtesy conversation.

title: Major Production Incident During Your Vacation
description: You're on vacation. A Sev1 incident fires and your team is handling it. Your manager pings you asking for status.

title: PM Wants to Ship a Feature You Know Will Create Tech Debt
description: PM has committed to a deadline with stakeholders. Meeting the deadline requires cutting corners that will cost the team months of debt later.

title: Two of Your Engineers Are in Conflict
description: Two senior engineers disagree on a technical approach. It's gotten personal — code reviews are hostile, standup is tense, team morale is affected.

title: You Inherit a Low-Performing Team
description: You join as EM. In your first month you discover: 2 engineers should probably be on a PIP, the team's metrics are worst in the org, morale is low, and the previous EM left because of burnout.

title: Layoffs Are Coming and You Know Before Your Team
description: Your Director told you confidentially: 20% RIF next week. You know who's affected on your team. You can't tell anyone yet.

title: Your New VP Wants to Change Everything
description: New VP joins. They want to re-org, change tech stack, adopt new processes, and reset all roadmaps. Your team is anxious.

title: You Discover a Senior Engineer Is Quietly Job Searching
description: Through the grapevine (or obvious calendar gaps), you realize one of your senior engineers is interviewing elsewhere. They haven't told you.

title: Your Team Needs to Deliver a Critical Migration Under Tight Deadline
description: Leadership committed to migrating off a legacy system in Q3. Your team owns it. The deadline is real (vendor contract expiration). Scope is larger than estimated.

title: Calibration Committee Wants to Downgrade Your Engineer's Rating
description: You submitted 'Exceeds Expectations' for a strong senior engineer. In calibration, peer managers are pushing for 'Meets' based on cross-team comparison. You disagree.

title: A Cross-Team Initiative Is Stalled Because No One Owns It
description: An important cross-org project has been discussed for months but nobody is driving it. Multiple teams would benefit but each expects the other to lead.

title: Your Manager Asks You to Rate Everyone 'Meets Expectations'
description: Your Director says the org needs to compress ratings this cycle. They want fewer 'Exceeds' ratings. You have 3 engineers who genuinely exceeded.

title: You Need to Build a New Team From Scratch
description: You've been given headcount to build a new team for a greenfield project. You have 6 months to hire 6 engineers and deliver first milestone.

title: One of Your EMs Is Struggling (Director Scenario)
description: One of your EMs is underperforming: their team's metrics are declining, skip-level feedback is concerning, and the EM seems overwhelmed.

title: Production Outage Caused by Your Team's Deploy
description: Your team deployed a change that caused a major production incident. Customers are affected. Leadership is asking what happened.

title: You're Asked to Take on Scope That Doesn't Fit Your Team
description: Your VP wants your team to own a new area that doesn't align with your team's expertise or mission. It's a political hot potato nobody else wants.

title: A Key Platform Dependency Is Unreliable and the Platform Team Won't Prioritize Fixes
description: Your team's reliability is suffering because of an upstream platform dependency. The platform team acknowledges the issue but has higher priorities.

title: Your Team Has Zero Diversity and You're Told to Fix It
description: HR/leadership points out your team is homogeneous. You're asked to 'improve diversity' in your next hires.

title: You Strongly Disagree with a Decision Made Above You
description: Your Director/VP made a strategic decision you think is wrong. It directly affects your team's direction.

title: You're Preparing for Your Own Promotion to Director
description: You've been a strong EM for 2+ years and want to make the jump to Director. What do you actually need to demonstrate?

title: DORA Metrics Show Decline But Team Feels Fine
description: Your DORA metrics have been trending down for 2 quarters — deploy frequency dropped 40%, lead time increased 3x. But team morale is fine and nobody is complaining. Your VP saw the dashboard and is asking questions.

title: Budget Cut: Lose 20% Headcount, Keep Critical Deliverables
description: Company announces 20% headcount reduction. You have 25 engineers across 4 teams. You need to identify 5 positions to cut while maintaining delivery on your top-3 commitments. You have 2 weeks before the announcement.

title: Security Audit Finding: Critical Vulnerability in Production
description: Internal security audit found a critical vulnerability (e.g., unencrypted PII in logs, open S3 bucket, SQL injection vector) in your team's production service. Security team has given you a 72-hour remediation window. Your team is mid-sprint on a high-priority feature launch.

title: Your Team's Tech Stack Becomes Deprecated Company-Wide
description: Platform team announces your primary framework/language is sunset. Migration timeline is 18 months. You have 100K lines of code in the deprecated stack, active feature development in flight, and no one on your team has deep experience with the target stack.

title: Merging Two Teams After Acquisition/Re-org
description: Company acquired a startup. You're responsible for merging their 8-person team with your 12-person team. Different tech stacks (they use Python/Django, you use Java/Spring), different cultures (startup speed vs. enterprise process), different processes (they have no sprint planning, you run 2-week sprints with full ceremonies). Some role overlap exists. Both teams are anxious about who stays, who leads, and what changes.

title: Managing Through a Major Security Incident (Data Breach)
description: Security team discovers unauthorized data access to your team's service. Customer PII (names, emails, hashed passwords) may be compromised. The scope is unclear — could be hundreds or millions of records. Legal, PR, and the exec team are involved. Your team owns the affected service. The incident is already escalated to the CEO. Clock is ticking on regulatory notification requirements (72 hours under GDPR).

title: Your Skip-Level Reports Are Unhappy With Their EM
description: In skip-level 1:1s, multiple engineers (3 out of 7) express frustration with their EM. Recurring themes: lack of career development conversations, micromanagement on technical decisions, poor communication about team priorities, and feeling unheard. The EM has been in role for 18 months and was promoted from within. Their self-assessment is that things are going well.

title: Budget Is Frozen But Commitments Remain
description: Mid-year budget freeze announced. No new hires (you had 4 open reqs), no new vendor contracts, limited travel and conference budget. But your Q3-Q4 commitments haven't been adjusted. Leadership expects delivery on the original roadmap. Your team is already at capacity, and two of the open reqs were for a critical new initiative that starts next quarter.

title: Leading a Cost Optimization Initiative (FinOps)
description: CFO mandates 30% cloud cost reduction across engineering. You're asked to lead the initiative for your org (4 teams, ~40 engineers). Current monthly spend is $2M across AWS services. No one has a clear picture of what's driving costs. Teams have never been held accountable for infrastructure spend. Finance wants a plan in 2 weeks and results within the quarter.

title: Managing Through a Hiring Freeze
description: 6-month hiring freeze announced company-wide. You have 3 open reqs mid-pipeline — one candidate just passed the onsite, another is in final round, and a third is at phone screen stage. Your team of 9 is already stretched across 3 projects. Two senior engineers are showing signs of burnout. One mid-level engineer recently mentioned they've been getting recruiter outreach. Attrition risk is real and you can't backfill.

title: Your Product Is Being Sunset/Deprecated
description: Leadership decides to sunset your team's product — a service with 50K active users. Revenue doesn't justify continued investment. Users need to be migrated to an alternative (internal or third-party). Timeline is 9 months. Your team of 10 engineers built this product over 3 years. They're anxious about their futures — will they be laid off, reassigned, or forgotten?

title: Quarterly Planning When Product and Engineering Disagree on Priorities
description: It's planning season. Product wants to invest heavily in new features for a key customer segment. Engineering wants to pay down critical tech debt that's causing weekly incidents. Both sides have compelling data. You need to facilitate alignment.

title: Asked to Build Something That Conflicts with Your OKRs
description: A VP from another org asks your team to take on an urgent project that doesn't align with your quarterly OKRs. Your manager seems supportive of helping. Taking this on means dropping or delaying a committed OKR.

title: Your Team's Delivery Predictability Has Collapsed
description: Over the past two quarters, your team has missed 70% of committed sprint goals. Stakeholders are losing trust. The team feels demoralized and says estimates are impossible given constant interruptions and changing requirements.

title: You Inherit a Team with No Operating Cadence
description: You've just taken over a team that has no regular standup, no sprint planning, no retrospectives, and no documented on-call process. Work gets done through Slack threads and ad-hoc requests. The team is productive but chaotic, and knowledge is siloed.

title: Your Team Culture Is Deteriorating After Rapid Growth
description: Your team doubled from 6 to 12 in 3 months. Skip-level feedback reveals new hires feel excluded, original team members feel their culture is gone, and collaboration norms are breaking down.

title: Addressing a Toxic Senior Engineer the Team Works Around
description: Your most technically skilled senior engineer is dismissive in code reviews, dominates discussions, and makes junior engineers afraid to speak up. The team has learned to 'work around' this person, but you're losing good people.

title: Asked to Do More With Fewer People After Layoffs
description: After a round of layoffs, your team lost 3 of 10 engineers. Leadership still expects the same deliverables. Team morale is low, survivors are anxious, and you need to figure out what's actually possible.

title: Communicating a Major Technical Decision Not Everyone Agrees With
description: After an RFC process, you've decided to migrate from microservices back to a modular monolith. Senior engineers are split — some are excited, others feel their microservices expertise is being devalued. You need to communicate the decision without creating factions.

title: Your Team Has Communication Debt — Decisions Aren't Documented
description: Your team has grown from 5 to 15 people. Key technical decisions live in Slack threads, hallway conversations, and individual memories. New hires can't find context. The same decisions are relitigated monthly. You're drowning in 'quick syncs'.

title: High Performer Wants Promotion But Isn't Ready
description: Your best engineer is pushing hard for promotion to Senior. They're technically excellent and deliver consistently, but they lack the influence, mentoring, and scope leadership expected at the next level. They're getting impatient and you're worried about retention.

title: Your Interview Process Is Rejecting Good Candidates
description: Your team has been hiring for 4 months with zero offers extended. Recruiting says candidate quality is high, but your interviewers keep saying 'not a strong enough signal.' You suspect the interview process itself is the problem.

title: Your Team Is Agile in Name Only
description: Your team runs 'sprints' but nothing is really iterative. Sprint planning is task assignment by the EM. Retros generate action items nobody completes. Standup is a status report to you. The team jokes about 'waterfall with standups.'

title: Leadership Wants Engineering Productivity Metrics Yesterday
description: Your VP asks for a 'developer productivity dashboard' by next month. They want to see engineering ROI. Your team currently has no metrics infrastructure. You know that naive productivity metrics can be destructive.

title: Product and Engineering Have Separate Roadmaps
description: You discover that PM has a roadmap they share with stakeholders, and your engineering team has a separate technical roadmap. The two don't align. PM is frustrated that engineering is 'doing their own thing.' Engineering is frustrated that PM doesn't account for technical investment.

title: Your New Engineering Manager Is Struggling With the IC-to-EM Transition
description: You promoted your best senior engineer to EM 3 months ago. They're still writing code 50% of the time, 1:1s are technical problem-solving sessions, and skip-level feedback reveals reports feel unsupported. Your new EM is frustrated that 'management is keeping me from real work.'

title: Building Incident Readiness Before Your First Major Outage
description: Your team owns a growing service but has never had a serious incident. There are no runbooks, no defined on-call rotation, and no incident response process. You know it's a matter of when, not if.

title: Your On-Call Rotation Is Burning People Out
description: Your on-call engineers are getting paged 10+ times per week. The same alerts fire repeatedly. Morale is cratering. Two engineers have asked to be removed from the rotation. You're losing people to teams with better operational hygiene.

title: Your Metrics Are Being Gamed and Everyone Knows It
description: Leadership set a deployment frequency target. Your team is now deploying tiny changes to hit the number, but cycle time is actually worse and code review quality has dropped. Engineers are cynical about measurement.

title: Your Team Keeps Failing Security Audits With the Same Findings
description: For the third year in a row, your external audit surfaces the same categories of findings: stale access permissions, unpatched dependencies, and missing encryption at rest. Your team scrambles before each audit but nothing sticks. Leadership is frustrated.

title: Balancing Security Risk With Shipping Speed After a Close Call
description: A near-miss security incident revealed that a feature shipped without a threat model — a misconfigured API endpoint was exposing customer PII to unauthenticated requests, caught in production monitoring before data was exfiltrated. Leadership wants to know how this happened and what you are doing to prevent it.

title: Scaling Your Interview Process From 5 to 50 Hires Per Year
description: Your team went from hiring 1-2 engineers per quarter to needing 10+ per quarter. Your ad-hoc interview process worked fine at low volume but now you're seeing: inconsistent evaluations between interviewers, candidates getting wildly different interview experiences, no data on what predicts success, and your best engineers spending 30% of their time interviewing.

title: Running Your First Cross-Team Performance Calibration
description: You've been asked to lead calibration across 4 engineering teams (~30 engineers). Each manager has their own standards — some are generous, some are strict. There's no shared vocabulary for what 'exceeds expectations' means. You need consistent, fair outcomes.

title: Mobilizing Your Team for a High-Stakes Deadline
description: Your team has 6 weeks to deliver a major feature that would normally take 12. It's a real business-critical deadline (contract commitment, not artificial urgency). You need to supercharge execution without burning people out.

title: Building Team Culture Through Intentional Rituals
description: Your team ships reliably but lacks cohesion. Engineers don't understand business metrics, don't contribute to roadmap discussions, and treat culture as 'something HR does.' Retros feel perfunctory and nobody proposes ambitious improvements. You want to move from a group of individuals to a genuine team.

title: Rebuilding Psychological Safety After Organizational Disruption
description: Your organization just went through layoffs, a major re-org, or leadership change. The remaining team is disengaged — people avoid speaking up in meetings, nobody challenges decisions, risk-taking has stopped, and your best performers are quietly interviewing. Trust has evaporated.

title: Navigating Your First Annual Engineering Budget Cycle
description: You've been promoted to a role where you now own budget planning for the first time. You need to present a headcount plan, tooling budget, and infrastructure forecast to finance and your VP. You've never done this before and don't want to show up with a wishlist that gets cut in half.

title: Everything Is Priority Zero and Your Team Is Drowning
description: Every initiative in flight has been labeled 'highest priority' by a different stakeholder. Your team is context-switching between 5 workstreams, nothing is finishing, and engineers are frustrated. You tried pushing back but each stakeholder explains why theirs is genuinely the most urgent. Sprint commitments are meaningless.

title: Managing Tech Debt Strategically Without Stopping the Roadmap
description: Your team has significant tech debt that's slowing delivery, but you can't stop the roadmap for a multi-month cleanup. Product is sympathetic but won't give you a quarter of dedicated refactoring time. Engineers are frustrated by working around old decisions. Previous 'tech debt sprints' produced feel-good cleanup that didn't move the needle on actual velocity.

title: Making a High-Stakes Technical Decision Under Time Pressure
description: You need to decide between two architectural approaches for a critical project. Both have significant trade-offs. Your team is split. Leadership wants an answer by Friday. The wrong choice will be expensive to reverse. You're feeling pressure to either over-analyze (missing the deadline) or decide too fast (regret later). Previous big decisions have been revisited repeatedly because they weren't well-documented.

title: Your Onboarding Is Broken and New Hires Are Struggling
description: New engineers take 6+ months to become productive. They report feeling lost in their first weeks, unsure who to ask for help, and overwhelmed by undocumented tribal knowledge. Your most recent hire quietly admitted in their 1:1 that they considered leaving in month two. Meanwhile, your tenured engineers complain they spend too much time answering basic questions.

title: Responding to a Critical Dependency Vulnerability
description: A CVE is published for a widely-used open source dependency in your stack (think Log4Shell, XZ Utils-class events). The vulnerability is rated critical. Your team doesn't know how many services are affected, there's no bill of materials, and leadership is asking for a status update. Security is asking when you'll be patched. You're not sure where to start.

title: Putting an Engineer on a PIP Designed to Succeed
description: An engineer on your team has been underperforming for months despite verbal feedback and informal coaching. You've documented the pattern and HR agrees a formal Performance Improvement Plan is appropriate. You've never run a PIP before and you're unsure how to make it genuinely developmental rather than just a paper trail to termination. The engineer is anxious and the team is watching.

title: Your Project Is Going to Miss Its Deadline
description: You're three weeks from a committed deadline and you've realized the team won't make it. The gap isn't small — you're looking at 2-4 weeks of additional work. Your VP has already communicated the date to customers. Product is counting on this for their quarterly goals. You're dreading the conversation but every day you delay makes it worse.

title: Introducing Engineering Metrics to a Team That Has None
description: Your engineering organization has no systematic metrics. Leadership makes decisions based on gut feel and anecdotes. When asked 'how is engineering doing?' you struggle to answer beyond 'we shipped X features.' You may not even have the tooling prerequisites — no CI/CD pipeline, manual deployments, no incident tracking — which means jumping straight to DORA or SPACE feels premature. You want to introduce metrics but you're worried about creating a surveillance culture or picking the wrong things to measure.

title: Killing a Project That Should Have Died Months Ago
description: A major initiative has been running for 6+ months with growing scope, shifting requirements, and declining team morale. Nobody believes it will deliver the original value, but there's significant sunk cost — engineering hours, leadership credibility, customer promises. You suspect the right move is to kill it, but everyone is afraid to be the one to say it.

title: Your Top Candidate Just Declined — Winning in a Competitive Talent Market
description: You've lost three of your last five top candidates to competing offers. Your interview process is solid, candidates reach the offer stage enthusiastic, but they take another offer at the last moment. Your employer brand isn't strong enough, your compensation is competitive but not leading, and your closing process is too slow. Leadership is frustrated by open reqs that stay unfilled for months.

title: Your VP Wants Engineering to 'Own Security' But Nobody Has Expertise
description: Your VP has decided that security should shift left into engineering. There's no dedicated security team, no AppSec engineer, and nobody on your team has deep security expertise. A recent incident — a feature shipped with a known SQL injection vulnerability because 'security didn't review it in time' — has made this an urgent priority. You're expected to embed security into the development lifecycle, but your engineers see security as 'not my job' and compliance requirements are growing.

title: Driving Culture Change Against Organizational Resistance
description: You've been hired or promoted to improve engineering culture, but the broader organization actively resists change. Legacy norms, hostile leadership, or institutional inertia work against your efforts. Your skip-level doesn't see culture as a priority, peers are indifferent or defensive, and your team is cynical from failed past initiatives. You believe the culture needs to change, but you lack the organizational power to mandate it.

title: AP-74: The Big-Bang Deploy — Team batches weeks or months of changes into monolithic releases, turning every deploy into a high-risk event. Weekend war rooms, rollback plans, and post-deploy firefighting become the norm, and deploy frequency drops because nobody wants to trigger the next crisis.
description: Team batches weeks or months of changes into monolithic releases, turning every deploy into a high-risk event. Weekend war rooms, rollback plans, and post-deploy firefighting become the norm, and deploy frequency drops because nobody wants to trigger the next crisis.

title: AP-75: The Vanity OKR — Team sets OKRs that are either so vague they can't be measured, so easy they're always green, or so disconnected from work that nobody references them. Goal-setting becomes a quarterly ritual with zero impact on daily decisions, and the team can't articulate what success looks like.
description: Team sets OKRs that are either so vague they can't be measured, so easy they're always green, or so disconnected from work that nobody references them. Goal-setting becomes a quarterly ritual with zero impact on daily decisions, and the team can't articulate what success looks like.

title: Restructuring Teams Around a Platform Strategy
description: Multiple product teams are independently building similar infrastructure — authentication wrappers, data pipelines, deployment tooling, notification services.

title: Building and Defending a Strategic 'Not Doing' List
description: A framework for establishing and defending explicit scope boundaries — creating a documented list of deprioritized work that protects focus and forces stakeholders to trade off rather than pile on.

title: Running a Build-vs-Buy Decision for a Critical System
description: Your team needs a capability — observability platform, feature flag system, CI/CD pipeline, identity provider, or similar infrastructure.

title: Establishing a Remote-First Operating Rhythm
description: Your team is distributed across time zones (or transitioning from co-located to hybrid/remote).

title: Designing OKRs That Actually Drive Engineering Behavior
description: Your organization uses OKRs but they're not working.
